oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Annual Spectacular Display of the Mystic Memphi 1876
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mardi Gras; Mystic Memphi; librettos;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Program of the Annual Spectacular Display of the Mystic Memphi, Mardi Gras, Feb. 29th, 1876, from 6 1/2 to 8 1/2 o' clock, P.M. In the Streets of Memphis; a sixteen page pamphlet describing the themes of twenty- eight tableaux; general theme of poetry divided into "Prelude", Grecian Epoch", "Roman Epoch", "Italian Epoch", "Spanish Epoch", "French Epoch", "German Epoch", "English Epoch", "American Epoch", and "Conclusion". Cover only, full text available in the Memphis Room.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Manuscript collection processed by John Jones
Chris Montoya
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Libretto of the Annual Spectacular Display of the Mystic Memphi 1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mardi Gras; Mystic Memphi; librettos;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Program of the Annual Spectacular Display of the Mystic Memphi, Mardi Gras, Feb. 13th, 1877, from 6 1/2 to 9 o'clock, P.M. In the Streets of Memphis, Tennessee. A twenty-eight page pamphlet describing the theme of twenty-one tableux; theme of India divided into "Ouro and Manu", "Aryan Phylosophy", "Birth of Brahma", "Siva, The Destroyer", "Caste", "On the Ganges", "Juggernaut", "Festival of the Serpents", "In the Jungle", "In the Desert", "In the Palanquin", "In the Bazar", "A Royal Durbar", "The Fire Worshippers", "The Great Akbar", "The Harem", "The Throne of the Peacock", "The Garden of Shalimar", "The Siesta", "Enslaved", and "Abandoned". [Cover only; full text available in the Memphis Room.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Manuscript collection processed by John Jones
Chris Montoya
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Description of the Street Pageant of the Ancient Ulks on Mardi Gras Eve 1878
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mardi Gras;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Program of the Street Pageant of the Ancient Ulks on Mardi Gras Eve, March 4th, 1878, from 6 1/2 to 8 o' clock pm in Memphis, TN. A 14-page pamphlet describing the 10 living picture exhibits; the pictures are listed as "Muse of the Ulks", "Hey Diddle Diddle", "Jack, The Giant Killer", "Ole King Cole", "Tom, Tom the Piper's Son", "Who Killed Cock Robin", "Robinson Crusoe", "Rip Van Winkle", "Grand Uproar", and "Re-United States". [Cover only; full booklet available in Memphis and Shelby County Room.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mardi Gras Contract - French
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mardi Gras; Mystic Memphi; business;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Contract between David P. Hadden representing the Society of Memphi and B. Nonnon, customer living at 50 St. Louis Street, New Orleans. Nonnon agrees to travel to Paris, France and produce costumes, masks, wigs and etc. according to the designs provided by the Memphi. Nonnon agrees to pay particular attention to designs numbered 16, 17, 18, 22, 95, and 96 and produce authentic replicas; costumes to include a Knight with copper armour; King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella; King Boabdil in armour with jewels; masks and wigs to represent Grant, DeSoto and Columbus; a dragon, an alligator, a serpent, an octupus, and three large decorated shells. Nonnon agrees to produce ninety-six other costumes according to numbered designs. Nonnon agrees to pay for the cost of shipping and that the order will be sent by a steamship of the German line departing from LeHavre, France no later than the first week of December, 1874. Nonnon is to receive $3,840 in five installments. The contract was drawn up in triplicate at Memphis, TN.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Manuscript collection processed by John Jones
Chris Montoya
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Digital Image ©2013, Memphis Public Library & Information Center. All rights reserved. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greene, Jenkins - Letter 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Greene, Colton; Jenkins, Albert Gallatin; politics; correspondence;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colton Greene, St. Louis, to Albert Gallatin Jenkins, House of Representatives, Washington City: urges Gallatin to be a "looker-on" and avoid taking rash actions; warns against underestimating the strengths of others; laments "southern political sagacity" in the handling of the "Kansas imbroglio"; asserts that now is not the time "to fight the negro question"; urges that Douglas (Stephen A. Douglas, Dem. Senator of Illinois) no longer be given support; explains that lack of money prevents visit to Washington this winter and will instead "play the Philosopher."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lady Friend Letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Greene, Colton; Civil War; correspondence;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: (Unidentified female friend), St. Louis, to Colton Greene: laments absence due to war of Greene and gives news of mutual friends; reveals that growing disgust with the world has caused her to become a Catholic and consider the convent; informs that she is estranged completely from "Mr. D."; asks that Greene write of his exploits and not forget "votre petite philly."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greene, Campbell Notes
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Greene, Colton; Civil War;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: (Series of notes concerning quarrel between Greene and Col. Campbell) To Col. Campbell from Colton Greene: censures assault upon Greene's character and challenges Campbell to a duel; names Col. Slayback as second; further notes from C. C. Rainwater (an additional second) to the effect that Campbell has disappeared and never responded to communication; memo in pencil; "Col. Campbell died during the month as I recall the facts. CG."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greene, Duke - Letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Greene, Colton; Civil War; correspondence;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: B. W. Duke, Attorney, Louisville, KY, to General Colton Greene: discusses publication of article written by Hines and Castleman about "the North Western Conspiracy", a war-time effort to free Confederate prisoners; relates that the authors wish to vindicate northern participants who were motivated not by southern sympathy but by abrogation of their own rights; reveals that Hines is ill and wishes to publish article before it is too late, preferably in the "Bivouac"; asks that Greene preserve letter and show it to Mr. Black.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lt. Col. Samuel J. Ward, in the field, to Col. Colton Greene: sending information requested that conversation with Capt. Hooper was simply an unofficial discussion of a rumour from "one gentleman to another" and that to Ward's knowledge, Greene never ordered evasion of the order.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greene, Duncan - Letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Greene, Colton; Civil War; correspondence;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joseph W. Duncan to Col. Colton Greene: explains that he has been unable to reply to messages because of illness but will send deposition soon that will clear Greene of all charges; requests Greene's support in obtaining promotion.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Walker, Greene - Letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Greene, Colton; Civil War; military; correspondence;
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Maj. J. A. Walker, Dardenelle, AR, to Col. Colton Greene: sending reply to Greene's note of 8/30; informs that Capt. Hooper never claimed to act for Greene in the matter of turning the mules over to the government and that, to Walker's knowledge, Greene never held any conversation on the matter.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mule Imbroglio Letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Greene, Colton; correspondence; Civil War; military;
